# What is R Markdown?
### A place for your code, notes, and output to live together

R Markdown files are designed to be used in three ways:

**.Rmd files** 
  - Develop code and ideas side by side
  - Run code in parts or as a whole
  
**Dynamic Documents** 
  - Knit together plots, tables, and results with narrative text
  - Ouptut in variety of formats - HTML, PDF, word, ppt, etc.
  
**Collaboration**
  - Use for collaborating with others (including future you!)
  - Anyone can read or run your code

# YAML
This section at the top of the RMarkdown file specifies core settings of the document
.pull-left[
- Specifies document basics
  - title
  - date
  - author
  - output format

- Can also include
  - theme
  - toc
]

--

.pull-right[
Settings are written in `key: value` pairs.
```{r eval=FALSE}
---
title: "Surveillance Report"
author: "Meenakshi Kushwaha"
date: "2022-09-13"
output: 
  html_document
---
```
]

???

# the `setup` chunk

- First code chunk of the RMarkdown document

- **Specifies universal rules or options for all other chunks**
  - e.g. echo option to show/hide code in output
  - can over-ride universal option setting in individual chunks as needed 

  
- Could be used to load libraries, datasets that you don't want to explicitly show in the report  

```{r, eval = TRUE, echo = FALSE, out.width = "100%"}

knitr::include_graphics(here::here("images", "rmd_1", "setup_chunk.png"))

```

Learn more about code chunk options [here](https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/lesson-3.html)

# Customizing reports - HTML

- Several YAML options for
  - themes
  - table of contents
  - showing or hiding code

### YAML example
```{r eval=FALSE}
---
title: "Surveillance Report"
author: "Meenakshi Kushwaha"
date: "2022-09-13"
output: 
  html_document:       #<<
    theme: flatly      #<<
    toc: TRUE          #<<  
    toc_float: TRUE    #<<
    code_folding: hide  #<<
---
```

---

# Customizing reports - Word

- Not many YAML options
- Cannot include HTML or interactive content 
  - cannot use `DT` package for tables
- Can use `flextable`  package
- Create a *template file* using Rmarkdown with custom styles
- Include the *template file* in YAML

```{r eval=FALSE}
---
title: "Surveillance Report"
author: "Meenakshi Kushwaha"
date: "`r Sys.Date()`"
output: 
  word_document:                    #<<
    toc: yes                        #<<
    refrence_docx: my_template.docx #<<
```

The Word doc created by RMarkdown will have the same formatting as specified in `my_template.docx`

---
# Parametrized reports

R Markdown documents can include one or more parameters whose values can be set when you render the report.

- Used to re-render the same report with distinct values for various key inputs, for example:

  - Producing a report specific to a department or geographic region.

  - Producing a report that covers a specific period in time.
  
  - Producing a report with or without certain sections depending on the audience.
  
  

---
# Option 1 
## Set parameters within YAML

- Provide default parameter value
```{r eval=FALSE}
---
title: "Surveillance Report"
author: "Meenakshi Kushwaha"
date: "`r Sys.Date()`"
output: 
  html_document
params: #<<
  hospital: "Central Hospital" #<<
  date: "2021-04-10"          #<<
```


---
# Option 2
## Set parameters within `render()`

```{r, eval=FALSE}
rmarkdown::render(
  input = "surveillance_report.Rmd",  
  output_file = stringr::str_glue("outputs/Report_{Sys.Date()}.docx"),
  params = list(date = "2021-04-10", hospital  = "Central Hospital")) #<<
```

**This will over-ride parameters set in YAML**
